column4: This was a neat experience even at minus 30. There are all sorts of people walking around that are properly dressed. It is a little spread out but not hard to navigate. I really enjoyed the one way road at the far end of Old Town but you will need a car to see this part.

We went to two of the Art Galleries that were really nice--Old Town and Gallery of the Midnight Sun. They are next to each other. Nice art work and nice elegant souvenirs were there. We walked a little farther on down the road and went to a glass workshop at the Old Town Glassworks. We were able to sandblast "etch"...

We were there later in the day so not much was open. We were surprised how spread out it was... in cold weather we weren't up for a long walk, but even a short walk gave us a taste of the funky vibe here.
While strolling around Old Town in Yellowknife, you will see many different colors of homes, some people call it Rainbow Valley! Very interesting place to visit!

Have good tourist attractions. Down to Earth Gallery and Gallery of the Midnight Sun give information of the old town from the early days to present.Art and crafts Yellowknife available at the galleries.

The road is winding and getting on to Latham Island which is part of Old Town shows a prettier part of Old Town. The variety of home styles is interesting. Some of the houses are perched up on high rocks. If you go far enough along the road on Latham Island you reach D'elo which is a first nation neighbourhood....
Great, lots to see, shops very interesting even if not buying, the outdoor store is worth a visit and the terrain is suitable for all to walk.
The views of the lake are great from around Old Town and it has charming character with whimsical houses. Everything is an easy 20 minute walk away.

We stayed in Bayside B&B in Old town. And it was a good choice. The town have some great views.. of the Great Slave lake and even of Downtown from the Pilot's monument. There are restaurants with great foods, and some art galleries in this place
Old Town is an eclectic mix of businesses in old buildings as well as modern residences. Be careful walking as streets, etc. are uneven. We went to specific stores, etc. rather than just wander.

This is an area of the historic Yellowknife that you will want to explore on foot. Easy to walk around. Can drive, but mostly one-way roads, with limited parking. We kept going back to enjoy the food and shopping and scenery and interesting architecture.
We loved the view. So many different ships and boats. Various little shops. We went to the rock view and the view was amazing. We could see old town quite well from there
so many things to do. coffee shops, glass shops and galleries with fur shops along the way. also, the views of the lake are breathtaking

Worth the time spent strolling through. I went twice, as the first time I went was on sunday, and not too much was open. It was much better the second time, and I had an app on my phone that talked about the historic sites there.
trundled down from (new) town, the pub we were hoping to have lunch at was closed (?) but the shops and scenery were great. Especially the lookout and the hardware store.
A great place to unwind and get a feel of what it was like to be in the far North years ago. Be sure to eat at the "Wildcat". Also check out the Float planes at the water front. Pretty spot.
Old town has a charm about it. Lots of history and very quaint. Many delightful restaurants to fill your tummy. There is a wonderful brew pub with very delicious beer and very friendly staff

Walking through old town you can really get a feel for what life must have been like 100 years ago in the north. You can get an appreciation for what it must have been like to live in a small wooden structure year round right next to life today. Look for the Ragged A** road. There are a number of...

I really enjoyed walking through Old Town each time I have gone. The large shops are great (be sure you are buying local if you want a true souvenir). However I really enjoyed the small shops (some out of homes) and found many handmade local treasures. View from the top of the rock is quite spectacular!
There are docks, colourful buildings, historical sites, and parks all over Old Town. The most memorable site was the residential buildings all coloured up.
So many eclectic places to see, eat or do things at. A little something for all. Some really interesting history for the area.

Old Town is good for walking and chilling, but it looks pretty run down. It definitely needs a coat of paint or two, and it would be nice if someone can run a lawn mower and perhaps plant some flowers --- just to make it look a little prettier.
A very cool area. Charming at times. We rated all the restaurants 3 or 4 stars. Climbing up to the monument is a must--amazing views of Back Bay and Yellowknife/Houseboat Bay.

Visiting this area gives a sense of life when the community was developing. There are spots for food and beverage, the harbor, interesting old buildings and some newer homes perched over the harbor. There are some shops with local art and crafts.

Yellowknife has limited activities and we were here to celebrate the longest day of the year. June 20 was super cool and the sun was up all night. Yellowknife is separated into three separate district, Old town, Newtown, and uptown.Old town is where the city of Yellowknife was born. Super important in the historical history of the city. Old...
Lots to see and do in Old Town. The restaurants were awesome. The views around the lake are amazing. We had a great time wandering around, eating and drinking in Old Town.

I did the walking tour of Old Town recently and had an amazing day. I went alone, so you don't have to worry about problems. I wandered around and looked at local art, had breakfast, and saw a lot of very interesting things. Bought gifts and sat on benches and had a wonderful day.Very relaxing,
Loads of artists, a real enclave- a must-see when you're in Yellowknife! There are plenty of shops with an eclectic assortment of goods.

Old town is very historical and very rustic. No matter where you come from you need to go to old town. You need to feel the beautiful history of Yellowknife. Once you cross the bridge from New town to old town you feel like you've stepped back time. But don't get fooled by the beautiful new homes built on Canadian...
after5 days searching the aurora, we moved to this old town area , it is more city look than our first super 8 hotel area. The taxi costed me 18'canadian dollars.
We spent the morning in Old Town. We had breakfast, wandered a few of the shops and galleries and really enjoyed all the nice, friendly folks we met. Very nice way to spend a few hours!

Amazing friendly people,wonderful galleries,Bullocks Bistroe and Dancing Moose were super places to dine.Especially loved our visit with Laura,Dannyand their cat Silver!The Wildcat was not open till the spring...sorry to have missed the heritage site!
Old town is my favorite part of yellowknife. Just to wander around. Very cool architecture and great views. A couple of cool shops there as well
Drive on the ice road, see the Northern Lights, Eat at Bullocks, Buy art at the Midnight Sun Gallery and the Glass Works.
buy your Canada Goose coats there. eat at Bullock's or Dancing Moose Cafe. browse gift shops. watch planes take off by Air Tindi. visit the ice castle. and so on..
Historic area just outside of the downtown with shops and galleries to wander through. Love this part of YK

A very charming and historical area of Yellowknife, full of local shops, galleries, restaurants and breweries. Take a walk, cruise some shops and have a beer, it will be time well spent. Also, the Dettah ice road starts near the old town, do not miss it.
So the reviews are really like it is , theres some nice people and good places but then theres others that are totally not , so for this its a average mark, sorry
You will visit Old town. Little boutiques, cool restaurants, the Pilots Mounment and views of the bays
Yellowknife old town is really old town. This town is just a couple of streets and could finished it within like half a day of walking around it. It was really pleasant to walk around:
Quirky and eclectic, with lots of little streets to wander around and many shops to stop into, plus the only brewery in town, and the best restaurant. Easy to walk out onto the lake from here as well
Small scale but a fun place for kids. We went there in a sunny afternoon and took a lot of good pictures. Only costs $5 per person.
Old Town Yellowknife offers the best eats and shopping experiences. Especially all the local artists items and collectables.

Yellowknife is a town with a lot of history. The first thing you do is go visit the Visitor Center and get your information before anything. You have so many difference nationality living there, I was surprise to find that they have really good places to eat. They even have their own brewery! Planning on going in the summer.

Old town is a beautiful part of Yellowknife. There are many things to see and many buildings to explore in the old town. It's also in a great location and you're surrounded by water and the lake on both sides of this peninsula. It is certainly worth the trip and the walk to see This Magnificent part of town.

We downloaded the Balado walking tour which was excellent - it was like having a personal guide that made for a wonderful and fascinating few hours. I think there are other good guides. It really helps understand Old Town and appreciate it much more.This was very worthwhile and a highlight of the visit to Yellowknife.

The Old Town of Yellowknife is the historical hub and the social heartbeat of this quirky and fascinating community. The buildings date back from the 1930s, which may not sound impressive, but given that they are mostly wooden miners' shacks, it is remarkable.In the winter, one can drive out on the ice and experience an "ice road", marvel at...
It keeps traditional YK style. Very lovely small village you have to go. The most of sweet shops are here, and you will love there.

a few nice and different little places to find native souvenirs and such, some hand crafted things. a nice little piece of culture history. Interesting buildings and area, some nice views of the lake.

A short walk from the main business section of town. Some interesting old buildings along with new builds. On the lake and some great views. Yacht club gives a good vantage point. A new brewery and restaurant is a possible highlight although I didn't go in.

We did a drive through and around the town. Stopped by a few places. It is an interesting place, but nothing spectacular.The ice road next to it on the frozen Great Slave Lake we found it more exciting and interesting.
Old town is just awesome. They have small stores along the way where you can buy souvenir. Also it's quiet and beautiful. There's also an access point to frozen lake, which is fun to walk on.

I had heard of Old Town and was excited to go, but I wish I didn't. You could see all the signs that during tourist season it might be a happening place, but in October it was a complete waste of time. I spent three hours walking around and don't believe I missed 'the exciting bit' One nice gallery (Midnight...

We booked an BnB for a week in the Old town. It is your best way to experience life on ice lake, the old building and sights around the area.Taxi to main dining areas and shopping is between $7 - $13 depending on where in Yellowknife.
Not much to see except Pilot's monument. That place is worthy to see, you can see the whole town from there.

well if you are in Yellowknife, it is worth having a look - certainly better than wandering around downtown. But despite the few interesting sights (some of the homes, houseboats, float planes) - the main road is mostly a desolate collection of industrial buildings, many of which look empty or abandoned. Would much rather spend my time walking around the...

There are craft and gift shops, but walk south to Ragged A?? (can't use real name but it is what you think) Road and beyond, toward Great Slave Lake, and look at the houseboats. Then walk around the neighbourhood and look at the one room mining shacks that are still tenanted by people living off the grid - no running...
If you're going to Yellowknife be sure to tour around Old Town! There are so many neat houses and cool shops and restaurants to see!

Old town was OK, but as we were there in the shoulder season a few places were closed. While it was a comfortable walk around the town, the cafes were all closed, there was little to see or do other than go into the gift shops, or go to the Glassworks. Also, Old Town isn`t well publicised, so while I...

The Old Town is very different from the YellowKnife downtown. It is a unique experience. There are some arts and crafts stores for shopping, then stop-by the Bullocks for dinner. It is quite windy there.

This may be a little out of the way but it's worth the cab ride. There are several highly rated restaurants in the area. We liked Bullock's Bistro so much we went twice in 2 days!Don't miss Pilot's Monument near Bullock's. It's a healthy climb up some steps and offers a wonderful view of the waterfront. Great photo opps!...

The houseboats are fun to admire, you can check out the sea planes, there are some great novelty eateries and art galleries and it's a nice walk. Some of the cafes close early (around 4pm) so I'd suggest a midday visit.

We stayed at a B&B in old town and walked everywhere. Lots to see, lots of history, galleries, shops and a few places to eat. Got to take our picture next to the Ragged A Road sign ( trip advisor wouldn't let me use the full A word) and got to see some of the old miners shacks. Lots of...

old shops, pier and dock where houseboats or going out for fishing trip; access to Great Slave Lake. Lots of little shops around. If you come in winter time, this is where you can enter to the ice castle.

We visited Old town during both rain & Shine. You have to visit Old Town if you want to eat @ Bullocks, Great Fish Dinners, we ate there twice. The Dancing Moose is also in Old Town, very good for Fish & Chips. We also toured Yellowknife on a Float Plane which takes off from Old Town. Some unique homes...
Parking isn't always easy in this area, so best way to explore is by walking in the area, enjoying the view of the colorful harbour, stopping in the shops & restaurants, galleries in the area.

Our hotel was up in the New Town area, and people told us to walk down to Old Town. It was about a 20-25 min walk down there (which mean uphill back to New Town). In fairness, it was a holiday, so not everything was open -- but I was not overly impressed with Old Town. In fact, I'm not...

I have lived in Yellowknife for more than 50 years. I have seen many, many changes there in my life time! It still holds a uniqueness that only Yellowknife could boast of. Although it is advertised as historic I think that this is not as much important as is its unique construction of home and home town characteristics. Many historic...
Old Town is colorful and charming. There are shops and restaurants and lots of float planes to check out.

Most of the buildings a older than me and very historical. There are some good views and interesting shops and places to eat. I like history so anything old, like me, is of interest. How could a person go to Yellowknife without visiting the old historical part is beyond me.

There is a lot to see in the Old Town section of YK. Things such as the Wildcat Café, Bulloch's Bistro, the Pilot's Monument and so very much more. Old Town is easy to access from Franklin Avenue (the parking is pretty tight in places).
Real old town. Very basic. Lots of people walking around and biking. Went into two establishments with rustic original feel.
Nice to have a walk around Old Town. Older architecture. Restaurants like Bullock's Bistro and Wildcat Care. Bush Pilot's Monument also located in Old town. About one to two hours to explore.

The best way to see Old Town is to walk it on your own. There is an app you can download that can help guide you. Information on the app is at the Visitor Centre or you can pick up a brochure at your hotel. The Wildcat Café and Bullock's, two famous restaurants are in the area and are great...

A must to see! So many wonderful things to see by foot. Walking is the way to go! Take a bike if you wish, but just be aware that is very hilly, so you will get tired. Bring a snack for a picnic and water. Amazing
If you want to visit the mall or a resturant even a bar you must go to old town the wildcat cafe is a must do!
Walked through old town with some friends. It is a wonderful experience and shows the passage of time with regards to mining ebb and flow associated with the town. Abundant street art and painting.

The Old Town of Yellowknife is the city's heart and history, and no visit to the territorial capital should miss spending time wandering through the neighbourhood.There is a very good walking guide app available from one's app store, and this adds immensely to the experience, telling a fine history of individual properties and the characters that made Yellowknife what...
Walking down to old town in winter is a brisk hike but worth it to warm up at Bullocks. Summer is also nice to go to a café by the water.

A really neat place to visit. We stayed on one of the floating homes anchored out in the bay. Lots of neat little shops to wander in and out of, very unique restaurants, and a great view of planes taking off and landing in the harbour area.

If you don't want to walk there is a bus that goes to Old Town. Enjoyed looking at all the old buildings which give you a history of the area. Pilots monument gives you a good view of the city. Also wandered over to Lantham Island to look at the houses.
Im glad to be here on summer time. The view at bush monument is stunning. An afternoon at the dock is perfect. You can almost have evrything at Old town, from B&B, to restaurant, to museum.
August 2007, loved old town, funky little restaurants, spunky signs, quaint little houses, and all very walkable.

Highly recommend walking through old town on an afternoon in the summer, or driving through slowly in the winter. Visit the galleries, the dancing moose for lunch, or Bullocks/Wildcat for lunch/supper for SURE! Lovely waterfront area with a busy houseboat bay, and serene quiet back bay area.

Great place to go for a walk and experience the old Yellowknife. A few unique stores to visit and browse the local made items. A couple of very unique restaurants, like the Wildcat Café and Bullocks Bistro. The Pilots Monument is also located in this area. If you come to Yellowknife you must visit this area. Stop by the Old...
A must see when visiting Yellowknife. A few really nice shops, excellent scenery and includes the Wild Cat Cafe. You can't say you've been to Yellowknife unless the Wild Cat was on your itinerary
A must visit type of area with a lot of history and some very unique restaurants and shops. Take your time and walk the streets
This place is getting a bit more touristy but there are lovely houses and quaint little areas in this historic part of Yellowknife. Definitely worth a walk around on a nice day.
Old town gives you a sense of how Yellowknife started. All the buildings are cozy and on the shore of Slave Lake. .

A quick 20 minute walk down hill from downtown, this is an interesting area filled with history, nostalgia, architectural wonders and trendy must eat places! The gift shop gallery has a great selection of reasonably priced local art, pottery, carvings and other traditional souvenir items; Just Furs has a great selection to keep you warm; Make sure you drop into...
Fabulous shops and restaurants here. You will have a wonderful time visiting the general store and the local craft and artisan workshops. The restaurants are easily walkable
More history here than you would think.It was a great spot to view Yellowknife from Pilots Monument. And then there is the Wild Cat Cafe!
Very quaint and rural. Ice castle's $ 5 admission was quite fun and going down the ice slide is a must! A few ice sculptures were magnificent!
Loved walking down to Old Town and back in -31 deg, snowing, frozen lake, rustic buildings, designer new buildings.... fantastic

We took a city tour and went to the old town area. It was ok to learn about its history, but I am not necessarily jumping up and down.The houses built on stilts to prevent foundation cracking was interesting, but there wasn't anyone on the road during our entire drive.I wouldn't put this high on your priority list...

Not much to do in Yellowknife, so it was a good 15 min walking destination to the ice road and see the ice castle. Unfortunately, Bullocks Fish and Chips only opens at 4pm on Sunday.There was a fun fur shop and a gift shop to visit.

I joined a City Tour together with Ice Road Tour. The City Tour included an outlook tour + village tour. The tour was worth 1 visit. It was interesting to know that the houses at Yellow Knife do not have water pipes.
It's on the shore of the lake and is at one end of the dettah ice road.ther is the Ice Castle that was under construction(built every season by a local inhabitant and made of ice and snow blocks).

Everyone should take the time to enjoy the view from pilots monument (as well as the goings and comings of seaplanes and house-boaters.) a multitude of good restaurants scattered about the base (iconic bullocks / wildcat ranging to contemporary moose cafe). A bit daunting on foot. There are a number of tourist shops scattered about. High prices but good quality...

I was driving there. The buildings are great, but its difficult to park since the road is one way, and there are other tourists coming. There is a road bypass to the great slave lake itself. And it is great to see the whole Yellowknife when you drive to Pilots Monument. But when I go there, its so windy that...

The best part of being in old town in the winter for me was access to the ice road. I walked along it 3 mornings in a row for hours and loved the expansive feeling of the frozen lake. The morning sunrise and light was gorgeous. Met some friendly people along the way, even got invited into one of the...

Yellowknife is definitely an interesting place to visit, and for us Old Town was the most interesting part. There are good places to stay (we liked the Bayside B&B), good restaurants (the Dancing Moose Café, the Wildcat Café, and Bullock’s Bistro), and a unique community that can easily be explored on foot.The most obvious feature of Old Town is...
Loved the old part of town, lovely homes, and interesting places to visit. Glass shop and workshop worth a visit and great cafe - dancing moose!

A small and beatiful neighborhoodsEven you may not stay in the B&B in old town but definitely you must go there for the famous restaurants, historical buildings and experience the environment in this quiet placeIt also a nice place for aurora viewing

I think Old Town is the original site of Yellowknife and has the most ecclectic mix of architecture. Some unique shops and homes to see. Check out the one of a kind shop, Weaver & Devore, a small old fashioned northern/outfitter store. Gallery of the Midnight Sun has northern art, clothing, souvenirs, jewelry, and other things.

Old town was worth the walk out of town to kill a few hours in between nightly aurora chasing. Not a lot of attractions but taking in the lakeside aspects was nice. Go up to the lookout for a great view of the surrounds and particularly the rockiness of the terrain, Check out how the Yellowknifers solve putting up a...
what ever you are looking for you will find in old town. The people are friendly and really want people to ask questions.

The best things about Old Town are the galleries with northern art, although there are not as many of these as there are in other old towns we have visited. We particularly like the monument as you enter old town and reading about its meaning. Also there was a hardware/general store that was worth going through. What characterizes this old...

A short walk from downtown (couple km one way) this neighbourhood includes colorful homes, log cabins, some very dramatic apartments and homes on the bedrock overlooking the lake and various businesses as well as public docks.There are several shops (tourist stuff, glass works, carvings, etc) and a few restaurants - definitely worth a stroll - the murals on dumpsters...
Definitely eat at Bullocks and have the fish and chips. Out of this world!! It is quite an experience as well. Very rustic but delicious huge plates of food.

Old town is a small town. You can spend a day to come here. Enjoy your food in some cafe and restaurants.also can buy many gift and souvenir with nice price here. If love to eat fish. You also can buy white fish with a cheap price in the port. Enjoy it.
I really liked the feel for Old Town, colorful buildings and even painted dumpsters. We didn't do any shopping, but walked around and took in the sights.

You have to take the time to walk this unplanned quirky community which is full of local colour and northern stereotypes. If you do, you will love it, if you just pass through, you won't be impressed. Floating boat houses, float planes where ever you look, modern corrugated steel apartments historic shacks and prospector cabins, appropriately named "Ragged A** Road",...
It won't take more than a few minutes to drive around. You can see the houseboats and the historic buildings (Wildcat and Bullock's and the general store.

We walked around town and took in all the local features. Very different from big city life and interesting to see the original background featured on walls, on garbage cans etc. Very clean town, people were very friendly.

Definitely a must to visit while in YK. It is fun to see the various shops and restaurants -- a great place to walk around -- also, be sure to head up to Pilot's Monument for a great vista overlooking Yellowknife. If I was short on time, I would be tempted to miss Wildcat Café, but if you are a...
Well the prices in the eateries were high but there was LOTS to see and LOTS to buy. Very authenic souvenires!

Once you notice details like the painted dumpsters & decorated houses & entire apartments made of corrugated steel... you fall more & more in love with it. The waterfronts are privately owned, so don't expect a boardwalk, but you can see a nice view of both bays from the roads. The streets are notably busy with traffic, considering it's such...

Not much is terribly old in this old town, and it must be called this because it was the first part of the town to be settled, but it's fun to walk around (doesn't take long!), and it's worth driving across to look at some of the unique architecture in the adjacent Latham Island neighborhood.

After a weeks stay,Old Town started to feel like home.There is such a collection of homes and businesses there that it never gets boring.The roads are quite bumpy,but it does keep the traffic slowed down.

We walked around during daytime ... we went to ice-castle as it was located on Great Slave Lake. We went to Gallery of the Midnight Sun for quality souvenirs and then the famous road "Ragged XXX Road". (Tripadvisor website didn't allow me to write that word as it is profanity)On the way to Pilot's Monument, we stopped by Just...

This part of The 'Knife gives a good "look back" to how things were in the North back when it was a sleepy mining town. Not surprisingly it was founded and grew around the lake as this was the key point for the float planes of the day.Planes are still a major component of the daily life here and...

The was easy access to banks and Shoppers Drug Mart. The Black Night Inn was close by the Yellowknife Inn so a quick pint was close by. There is a Loblaws in Old Town and this is important because the Walmart on the New Town side did not have Meat, Milk, or fresh fruit. This place had everything.

We stayed 3 out of 4 nights in Old Town. There's so much to see in March. We stayed at Bayside Bed & Breakfast right on the water so we could see the planes taking off and landing on the ice runway. We drove on the 6km ice road to Dettah and back. Went to see the Ice Castle -...
This town has many cute houses.That make beautiful view.The center of town has the hill.If you climb the hill.You could see old town and yellowknife from there.

I am a resident and do not live in Old Town, but do much business there. It is best experienced by walking and dropping into the local stores, galleries, restaurants, aviation hangars and talking to folks. If you are lucky, you might even get a tour of a houseboat!

A very unique place to tour around and live! Interesting contrasts between old and new architecture, the local life and history. Leave yourself a few hours to walk around, you don't want to miss anything.

Old Town consists of a handful of relatively old (1930s) and some dilapidated buildings. Compared to a typical 5 star historical town, like Virginia City in Nevada,, Tombstone, Az, or the old town of Quebec city, this is a 1 star attraction. . .If you are coming to see the Northern Lights (a 5 star attraction in my opinion),...

Awesome! If you can't or don't want to go on a tour group to see the northern lights, there's a great place to see them in town. Just walk or head over to Pilot's Monument in Old Town (there's parking for about 10 cars there) and climb to the top and see it in the open sky. A great place...

This part of town deserves a fair amount of time and walking to really enjoy. Walk to the top of the hill to see the views and memorials to pilots of years gone by. Check out the old restaurants but be prepared to pay to enjoy them. Lots to see and do.

good galleries, lots of choices. Fun old stores. Parking was a bit of a hassle but we managed, its probably easier if you know your way around. Went on a boat tour for an hour of the lake immediately around the city - it was fun to see the houseboats.
Very quaint and interesting. Lots of local crafts and restaurants to pick from down on the waterfront.

We had intended to walk the 20 minutes to this part of town from the Explorer Hotel, but rain and cold beat us back. We heard great things from friends at the hotel about the Wildcat Café (newly renovated) and especially about the food at the Bistro kitty-corner from it (can't recall the name).

Fairly compact business district a modest walk from Yellowknife city center. Old, quaint, unique, even eccentric, houses and businesses. Yellowknife harbor is here. Good view from hilltop at Pilot's Monument.
Wander around for an afternoon and see the cool houses. Grab lunch or dinner at one of the restaurants and climb pilot's monument.

Well, the Canadian Shield, in your face. What a strange place. The houses are nuts, everything from big mansions on stilts to shacks on the Aborginal reservation with pickup trucks that run on tracks. A very unique piece of Canadiana. Go to the pilot monument for a great view of the town.

Old town is real and funky and full of artists. Northern glass studio/Down to Earth gallery is a wonderful place to stop. It's a cooperative of northern artists, many of them local. Right next to gallery of the midnight sun, which is nice but more production art, an high end sculpture.For true northern art with that Old town flair DTE...

There is so much in Old Town, you MUST see this if you go to Yellowknife. A lot of great restaurants and museums. I would highly recommend going to pilot's monument as well to get a great view of the lake and old town. Hit up Bullock's and the Smoke House too!

Loved the Old Town Glassworks workshop. They recycle wine and some liquor bottles into beautiful glasses, vases, some jewelry. The workshop teaches you how to take a bottle and transform it into the item you choose, prep it and sand blast a design onto it for a very unique functional souvenir. They also had some very reasonably priced prints by...
An area of Yellowknife with lots of little eclectic places to look around. Must visits are Old Town Gassworks ....
Gives you the feel for the place. Gallery of the Midnight Sun shop was fantastic. Get your keepsakes there (and bring your $$). A few good eateries. Quaint

Very authentic place to visit in Yellowknife and very close to the hotel. When you get there do not forget to visit the pilot monument that is up in the hill. U couldget the best view of the City of Yellowknife.
Very pretty with a lot of different sites to take in. Great shopping for heritage items. A little expensive, but worth the trip to the Old Town.

A tour of the Old Town, whether on foot, or in a vehicle (stopping and getting out of course) provides many interesting buildings to view and photograph. The sculptures and items of interest around 'Yellowknife Cultural Crossroads' were particularly interesting.

Lots of galleries and a few cafe's and B&B's. But they're all spread out around this small old town area. The best way to see it is to walk. Don't forget to check out the Pilot's Monument at the top of the hill.
The architecture throughout is something you sure don't see other places. It's great that it's all unchanged and the locals are friendly and interesting. If you bump into Walter, say hi !

Old Town is a beautiful area of Yellowknife that is situated on rock that stretches out into Great Slave Lake. The views are everywhere and it feels like being in a quaint, fisherman's village on the coast somewhere and not on a lake! Albeit a massive, beautiful lake in the N.W.T.! You can park in certain areas and walk or...
Loved Ragged Bottom Road. Not the right spelling but Trip Advisor said I was using profanity. Lots of super cool homes and a stunning view of the harbour and houseboats.
Like stepping back in time, It is very unique in its design, the houses are built on rock and it is very interesting to see the architecture.

Old town is just fun. It has the Wildcat Cafe, Ragged A?? (you can guess what is missing - sorry not profanity in reviews allowed) Road, Bush Pilots monument, the local fish guy, tourist shops selling local goods including beaver hides, slippers, carvings, etc. and Weaver and Devore which is an old general store that sells everything. From the top...

I have always loved Old Town and N'Dilo. Visit often. What I love the most about Old Town, though, is unfortunately disappearing. The charm and inviting lure has disappeared over the years with the introduction of fancy, expensive houses in place of the rustic beauty of what once was. Weaver's is awesome, though! Wonderful store and a great family -...
If you like looking at art locally made, this is the place to go. The other thing that is good about old town is the fresh fish and Bullocks Bistro are there

Old Town really shows you what Yellowknife is all about. Places to go, things to do, people to see. In the summer, come down to old town and climb up pilots monument and watch float planes take off of the lake. In the winter come to the art shops and go out on the ice and to the ice castle....

Great combination of funky buildings, a waterfront community of awesome houseboats that perfectly compliment a rugged shore of rolling Canadian shield. Float planes, shacks, lots of fine exploring to do on foot.

Other than the float planes, the Wildcat Cafe and an occasional "heritage" building, there isn't much to see in Old Town. Spend the 5 minutes driving around it just to say you went, but don't expect any great insight into Yellowknife's past.
A slice of old frontier, it was an interesting area to visit, with fun restaurants and a few unique stores.
We had a great time, walking down and around the Old Town trail and seeing the houses and shops and meeting some really lovely, genuine people.
Very scenic, was nice to see the various planes and boats. Nice to see all the different architecture.

Climb Pilot's Monument and watch the bush planes land and take of on Great Slave Lake. Take pictures of the houseboats, visit the many local artist shops who offer traditional crafts, carvings, glass work and fur. Have lunch or take stroll. Life moves slow up here in summer.June and early July are great for the "Midnight Sun".
each house original and different. loved the house boats - admore the people for their creativity
It was nice to learn about the unique Canadian north living style in the old town. There were some interesting architectures to check out.
Great Shops! The REAL way to experience Yellowknife! I live in the area myself an its right by the lake with so many activities! The best neighborhood in Yellowknife!

It's worth a drive thru. The drive itself is average since most of the view and houses are hidden but there are some good little shops down there. Gallery of the Midnight Sun is the best 'souvenir' shop in town. It has classy northern gifts...no cheap cheesy trinkets to be found here. I'm a local and I still buy from...
The shops in old town is great for gift ideas. Remember to checkout the glassworks shop, nice eco-friendly art.

What a great place is 'Old Town.' I've driven in this area several in the 10 days that I have been here. I enjoy the feel of this unique area. This rich area makes ones senses come alive. I was able to take a workshop at the Glass Recyclers Shop where I made a couple of items and learned that...

Old Town Yellowknife was a pleasure to see and walk around. We picked up some snacks at TJ's Nut Hut, headed over to Northern Lights Glassware to see some interesting art, then climbed up to the Bush Pilots monument which gives a FANTASTIC view of the entire area. From the controversial house boats to the active float planes and georgious...

If you want to get an idea of the close relationship between the land and the water in Yellowknife look no further than Old Town. This charming area is home to a number of tourist attractions (Pilot's Monument, Wildcat Cafe, etc.) and a marina.
